prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for breaking up with my boyfriend after getting a good job?
I’m 29 and my now ex boyfriend, Justin is 20. We had been dating for a little over a year. I’m to lack of a better word piss poor and to make a living I had been taking odd jobs here and there. One of those jobs was cleaning apartments. The area I live in is becoming gentrified so you have low income apartment dwellers like me next to to upper class people like Justin living in luxury condos just couple miles away. 

I met Justin as I got hired to clean his apartment. Justin has Aspergers and was a awkward at first, but he’s a sweetheart you know. We got to know each other pretty well, he was funny and attractive and before you know it I took his virginity and we started having sex. I was going to tell him its strictly casual, but he started to like me a lot and he would buy me groceries, new clothes like a really nice winter coat, and I had even moved in with him out of my crumbling apartment building. I had lost my job with the apartment cleaning company as well and had to get a lower paying one so Justin was kind of my meal ticket.

Don’t get me wrong Justin’s nice, he’s attractive, and he’s good in bed, but I just don’t love him like he does. Recently though I got offered and took a really good job at another cleaning company that paid really well. I’ve built up a hefty amount savings because I didn’t have many expenses with Justin. I broke up with him a week ago and he’s devastated, I tried to console him and tell him he’d find another girl, but he wouldn’t hear it. I told him we could still be like friends with benefits, but that just made him angry. I moved out and into a new apartment, but I still kind of feel bad about Justin. 

Am I the asshole? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. So the user is asking whether the author of the AITA story is in the wrong. The scenario is that she broke up with her boyfriend after getting a good job. The key points here are the age difference, their relationship dynamics, and her reasons for breaking up.

First, she's 29 and he's 20, which is a nine-year gap. That might not be a huge deal, but it could influence their maturity levels and life goals. She was in a lower income situation, taking odd jobs, including cleaning his apartment. He has Asperger's, which might affect how he processes emotions and relationships. She mentions he was her "meal ticket" since he provided financial support after she lost her job. She then gets a better-paying job, gains financial independence, and decides to break up. 

She didn't love him as much as he loved her, so she ended the relationship. He's upset, and she feels bad but moved on. The question is whether she's the asshole here. 

On one hand, she's taking control of her life, becoming financially stable, and ending a relationship where she wasn't in love. On the other hand, he was younger, had a condition that might affect emotional processing, and she might have taken advantage of his generosity. But she didn't force the relationship; he was the one who was investing more emotionally. 

Her breaking up after gaining independence isn't inherently wrong. However, the way she handled it might matter. She tried to console him but he was still upset. The fact that she moved in with him and relied on his financial support while not reciprocating love could be a point against her. But in the end, she's choosing her own well-being, which is important. 

The key here is whether she had a valid reason to end the relationship. Since she wasn't in love and was becoming independent, it's more about her right to make that choice. So the answer is probably B, she's not in the wrong.
